message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a pelvic fracture with associated nerve damage. The perineal bruising and pain with manual compression of the pelvis also support this diagnosis. Among the options, only pelvic splanchnic nerves are responsible for bladder and rectal function, so it is the most likely structure to be injured in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pelvic splanchnic nerves play a role in bladder and bowel control, and injury to these nerves can cause urinary incontinence. The other options do not directly affect urinary control. Perineal bruising and pain with manual compression of the pelvis suggest a pelvic injury, which can affect the pelvic nerves. Pelvic ultrasound showing a normal bladder suggests the bladder itself is not damaged.

We refer to the anatomy of the pelvis for help. Pelvic splanchnic nerves are responsible for controlling the bladder and urethral sphincter, and their injury can cause urinary incontinence. The other nerves listed do not have a direct role in controlling the bladder and urethral sphincter. The perineal bruising and pain with manual compression of the pelvis suggest pelvic trauma, which can lead to injury of the pelvic splanchnic nerves.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient has perineal bruising and pain with manual compression of the pelvis, it suggests injury to the pelvis. The pelvic splanchnic nerves play a major role in bladder control, and injury to these nerves can result in urinary incontinence. The other options are not typically involved in urinary incontinence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a pelvic fracture, which can result in injury to the pelvic splanchnic nerves, causing urinary incontinence. The other nerves listed are not commonly associated with urinary incontinence.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest damage to the sacral nerves or spinal cord. Among the options, Pelvic splanchnic nerves are responsible for parasympathetic innervation of the bladder and are more likely to cause urinary incontinence. The other nerves listed do not innervate the bladder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest damage to the pelvic splanchnic nerves, which control the urinary and anal sphincters. The genitofemoral, superior gluteal, and obturator nerves do not control these functions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and injury suggest pelvic fracture which can injure the pelvic splanchnic nerves, which innervate the bladder and can cause urinary incontinence. The other nerves listed do not innervate the bladder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pelvic pain and perineal bruising suggest injury to the pelvic region. Since there is no injury to the bladder found by ultrasound, the most likely cause of urinary incontinence is nerve damage, and pelvic splanchnic nerves are responsible for bladder control. Genitofemoral nerve controls the cremaster muscle and the scrotum or labia majora. Superior gluteal nerve controls the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, and obturator nerve controls the adductor muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest pelvic fracture, and injury to the pelvic splanchnic nerves can cause urinary incontinence because they provide parasympathetic innervation to the bladder detrusor muscle. Injury to the genitofemoral nerve, superior gluteal nerve, or obturator nerve would not cause urinary incontinence.
